awd_titl_txt: Quantitative Research Methods for STEM Education Scholars Program
awd_abstract_narration:
The project is supported through the EHR Core Research: Building Capacity in STEM Education Research (ECR: BCSER) competition that is designed to build individual capacity to carry out high quality fundamental STEM education research in STEM learning and learning environments, broadening participation in STEM fields, and STEM workforce development. 

This research institute involves a year-long training of two cohorts of 20 Quantitative Research Methods (QRM) Scholars via a one-week intensive institute on fundamental issues in research design, analysis, measurement, followed by onsite collaborative activities, and meetings with their assigned methods mentor and graduate student facilitator. Year-long interactions include live-stream workshops and a social network infrastructure to improve participant's skills in design and execution of research in STEM Education, with feedback from their methods mentor and a local content area mentor designated by the QRM Scholars as part of their application. Each QRM Scholar will be expected to work on a proposed study/activity during the year while they are being mentored, this may be in collaboration with other Scholars. A key component of this year-long experience will be a unique platform of electronic social infra-structure (e.g. WhatsApp, Facebook Group). The year will culminate with a capstone conference, wherein the Scholars present their work from the past year. Starting in year 2, this conference will also serve as the convening of the next year's Scholars (during which each new Scholar will be matched with a 'graduating' Scholar for networking).

Given the persistent underrepresentation of individuals from certain groups in STEM courses of study and careers, as well as concerns about achievement gaps in math and sciences across educational levels, this program will target early career scholars (within five years of their doctoral degree) with research foci on issues of access and equity of underrepresented populations in STEM within either K-12 or postsecondary settings. The design and analysis approaches to address research questions related to group comparisons, a key focus of studies to address equity, will play a special role during the week-long institute and the year of interaction. The STEM Education research of the 40 QRM Scholars over the two cohorts will be made rigorous in terms of study design, methods of measurement, and data analytical approaches. Each Scholar's work will make valuable and immediate contributions to the literature around issues such as STEM Education access, achievement gaps, and workforce diversity, but as part of the program, the QRM Scholars will develop a viable and fundable agenda for the coming years to ensure their continued high-level contributions to the field.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The QRM Program (2019-2022) trained 39 early career STEM Education researchers with research interests in STEM equity and inclusion in a variety of quantitative methods to increase the capacity for quantitative analyses in STEM education research (one scholar could not participate in the training due to personal Covid19 issues). Two cohorts of QRM Scholars were trained in the program for a full academic year, and each scholar conducted at least one quantitative research project. Starting with a week-long training institute in which they were introduced to a variety of quantitative concepts, scholars developed rapport with other scholars, and were assigned a quantitative methodology faculty mentor with expertise in design, statistical analysis, and measurement. During the cohort year, QRM Scholars had access to a software server and enrolled in at least 8 workshops such as multilevel models, structural equation modeling, and social network analysis (see proposal below for the full list of workshop topics). Additionally, they had regular meetings with their quantitative faculty mentor and attended optional weekly office hours with graduate student facilitators who assisted scholars with their research projects. As a result, QRM Scholars increased their own knowledge but also gained a deeper understanding of how quantitative methods can be applied and when to seek out a quantitative methodologist as a collaborator. As of this writing, our first cohort of scholars (selected via lottery of eligible applicants thus consisting of an RCT) had more change in citation counts after 3 years than the control on average (324.37 vs 246.22, p = .237, Hedge’s g = 0.238), and submitted at least 17 grants proposals for funding to internal university seed funding programs or external agency sources; seven of these proposals were submitted to NSF funding programs. One of the Cohort 2 Scholars recently was awarded an NSF Career grant. Importantly, across all Cohort 1 and 2 Scholars, 100 percent reported that their confidence regarding conducting quantitative research increased, with 57 percent indicating it increased “a lot.”  Increases were also reported in their confidence in collaborating with others (80%), writing a research proposal (77%), and framing research questions (80%). 

 

 

This program had considerable broader impacts, beginning with the training of 39 scholars who developed projects involving quantitative methods, most of which involved novel research questions and data collection, establishing new trajectories for research in the field of STEM Education. The potential reach that this training has goes well beyond the individual participants. Their own students have been affected and the scholarship and manuscripts, reviewed by the participants, have been improved. Additionally, the program is diversifying the field of quantitatively-trained STEM education scholars; Of the 39 participants, 31 are female, six are faculty at HBCUs, five are faculty at HSIs and, based on our knowledge, 24 are scholars of color. 

In the long run, the program 1) extends and broadens the training and research capacity of early career faculty and postdoctoral fellows regarding their research design, measurement, and analysis skills; 2) enhances diversity in STEM education through providing quantitative methodological mentoring and training to traditionally underserved early-career STEM scholars; 3) influences other training programs aimed at improving methodological capacity; and 4) contributes to the community of methodological rigorous oriented and evidence-driven STEM researchers.
